Translated by Imperial Decree The Buddha spoke of the five aggregates, namely the form aggregate, the feeling aggregate, the perception aggregate, the formation aggregate, and the consciousness aggregate.
What is the form aggregate?
It refers to the four great elements and the form derived from the great elements.
What are the four great elements?
They are the earth element, the water element, the fire element, and the wind element.
What are they again?
They are the solidity of earth, the fluidity of water, the heat of fire, and the lightness of wind.
Element means being able to uphold one's own nature and the form derived from it.
What is the form derived from the four great elements?

It refers to the eye faculty, the ear faculty, the nose faculty, the tongue faculty, the body faculty, form, sound, smell, taste, and part of the tactile object, as well as non-indicative form, and so forth.
Derived means the meaning of cause.
Faculty means the meaning of supreme, sovereign, and dominant, which is the meaning of faculty.
As for the term master, with whom is it the master?
It is said that the eye faculty is the master of the eye consciousness, because it gives rise to the eye consciousness.
In the same way, the body faculty is the master of the body consciousness, because it gives rise to the body consciousness.
What is the eye faculty?
It is that which takes form as its object, and has purity of form as its nature.
It is said that within the eye, a portion of pure form is like pure ghee. Because this nature exists, the eye consciousness can arise. Without it, it would not arise.
What is the ear faculty?
It is that which takes sound as its object, and has purity of form as its nature.
It is said that within the ear, a portion of pure form. Because this nature exists, the ear consciousness can arise. Without it, it would not arise.
What is the nose faculty?
It is that which takes smell as its object, and has purity of form as its nature.
It is said that within the nose, a portion of pure form. Because this nature exists, the nose consciousness can arise. Without it, it would not arise.
What is the tongue faculty?
It is that which takes taste as its object, and has purity of form as its nature.

It is pure form that pervades the tongue. Some say that on the tongue there is a small amount that does not pervade, like a single hair tip. Because this nature exists, the tongue consciousness can arise. Without it, it would not arise.
What is the body faculty?
It is pure form that takes touch as its object.
It is pure form that pervades the body. Because this nature exists, the body consciousness can arise. Without it, it would not arise.
What is form?
It is the object of the eye, including manifest color, shape, and indicative form.
Manifest color is of four kinds: blue, yellow, red, and white.
Shape refers to long, short, and so forth.
What is sound?

It is the object of the ear, including sound caused by the great elements that are grasped, sound caused by the great elements that are not grasped, and sound caused by both the great elements that are grasped and those that are not grasped.
The mind and mental factors are what grasp and hold. Living beings are what are grasped and held.
Sound caused by the great elements that are grasped refers to sounds such as the clapping of hands and speech.
Sounds that are not caused by the great elements that are grasped are like the sounds of wind, forest, and rushing water.
Sounds that are caused by both kinds of great elements are like the sounds of hands clapping or striking a drum.
What are smells?
They are the objects of the nose, good smells, bad smells, and neutral smells.
Good smells are those that, when combined with the nose, bring benefit to the continuity of the aggregates.
Bad smells are those that, when combined with the nose, bring harm to the continuity of the aggregates.
Neutral smells are those that, when combined with the nose, bring neither benefit nor harm.
What are tastes?
They are the objects of the tongue, sweet, sour, salty, pungent, bitter, and bland.
What is one part of tangibles?
They are the objects of the body, excluding the great elements, namely smoothness, roughness, heaviness, lightness, cold, hunger, and thirst, etc.
Smoothness means fine and soft, roughness means coarse and strong, heaviness means what can be weighed, lightness means the opposite.
Heat is the cause of cold, and touch is the cause of heat. This is a case of calling the cause by the name of the effect.

It is like saying that the appearance of the Buddhas in the world is happiness, expounding the true Dharma is happiness, the harmony of the Saá¹…gha is happiness, and practicing diligently together is happiness.
Although diligent effort and hardship are causes of happiness, they are said to be happiness.
This is also like that. Desire for food is hunger, and desire for drink is thirst. The explanation is the same.
The seven kinds of created touch and the previous four great elements are eleven kinds.
What are the unmanifest forms, etc.?
They are the forms that are manifest actions, born from samÄdhi, invisible, and unimpeded.
Manifest actions refer to bodily and verbal manifestations. They are of the nature of good, bad, and indeterminate.
The forms that are born from them refer to the forms that are born from those good and bad manifestations.
This cannot be indicated, and is therefore called unmanifest.
The forms born from samÄdhi refer to the forms born from the four meditations, etc.
This avijÃ±apti-rÅ«pa, which is the nature of derivative form, is called good restraint, bad restraint, etc., and is also called karma and also called seeds.
These various forms are briefly divided into three types:
1. Visible and resistant, 2. Invisible and resistant, 3. Invisible and non-resistant.
Among them, the visible and resistant refers to the colors, etc.
The invisible and resistant refers to the eye faculty, etc.
The invisible and non-resistant refers to the avijÃ±apti-rÅ«pa, etc.
What is the aggregate of feeling?
There are three kinds of feeling, namely pleasant feeling, painful feeling, and neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling.
Pleasant feeling refers to the desire for union when it ceases.
Painful feeling refers to the desire for separation when it arises.
Neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling refers to the absence of two desires.
The absence of two desires refers to the absence of the desire for union and separation.
Feeling refers to the cognition's reception.
What is the aggregate of perception?
It refers to the superior grasping of the characteristics of various objects.
Superior grasping means grasping with superior power.
It is like a very powerful person being called superior power.
What is the aggregate of mental formations?
It refers to all mental factors and formations not associated with mind, except for feeling and perception.
What are the remaining mental factors?
It refers to all formations associated with mind:

Contact, attention, volition, desire, resolve, memory, concentration, wisdom, faith, shame, conscience, non-greed, non-hatred, non-delusion, effort, tranquility, non-negligence, equanimity, non-violence, greed, hatred, pride, ignorance, views, doubt, anger, resentment, concealment, vexation, jealousy, stinginess, deceit, flattery, arrogance, harmfulness, shamelessness, lack of conscience, dullness, agitation, lack of faith, laziness, negligence, forgetfulness, distraction, incorrect knowledge, remorse, sleep, reflection, investigation.
These mental factors are five universal mental factors.
They are universal because they are present in all wholesome, unwholesome, and indeterminate minds.
Five are specific mental factors.
These five are each determined and inseparable in relation to specific objects. If one is present, all are present.
Eleven are good, six are afflictions, the rest are secondary afflictions, and four are indeterminate.
These four indeterminate ones are not true secondary afflictions, because they are common to both good and indeterminate natures.
The nature and function of contact, etc., should be explained.
What is contact?
It is the discernment of the union of the three.
The union of the three refers to eye, form, and consciousness, and so on.
The arising of these mental factors is called contact.
Its function is to serve as the basis for feeling.
What is attention?
It is the nature of causing the mind to be aroused.ğŸ”½It is the meaning of arousing and activating the mind and mental factors.
Its function is to hold and grasp the object of the mind.
What is conceptualization?
It is the nature of causing the mind to form merits, faults, and neither, and to create.
It is the nature of mental activity.
If this nature exists, the function of consciousness grasping objects is present, just as a magnet moves iron. Its activity is to impel wholesome, unwholesome, and indeterminate minds.
What is desire?
It is the nature of hoping for what is lovable and enjoyable.
Things that are lovable and enjoyable refer to what is seen, heard, etc. that is delightful. This means wishing for and seeking what is pleasant.
Its activity is to provide a basis for the exertion of vigor.
What is resolve?
It is the nature of approving what is known in regard to a definite object.
A definite object refers to the five aggregates, etc. As Vasubandhu says:
Form is like a mass of foam, feeling is like a water bubble, conceptualization is like a mirage, volitional factors are like a banana tree, and consciousness is like an illusion.
This is definite.
Or it is like the self-characteristics in which dharmas abide. That is to say, resolve arises in just this way.
What is called definite means the meaning of approving.
The other [mental activities] do not have the function of attracting and transforming, because these [mental activities] are superior and the others are not able to attract and transform.
What is memory?
It is the non-loss of the mind with regard to familiar things, and its nature is that of clear recollection.
Familiar things refer to things that have been previously experienced and practiced.
Its activity is that of acting as the support for non-dissipation.
What is samÄdhi?
It is the one-pointedness of mind with regard to an observed object.
The observed object refers to the five aggregates, etc., and to impermanence, suffering, emptiness, non-self, etc.
One-pointedness of mind means the meaning of concentration.
Its activity is that of acting as the support for knowledge.
Because the mind is concentrated, one can understand things as they really are.
What is discernment?
It is the discernment of dharmas with regard to those objects, and its nature is that of being drawn by correct principles, drawn by incorrect principles, or drawn by neither.
Those objects refers to the observed objects.
Discernment of dharmas means that with regard to the specific and general characteristics of all dharmas, discernment is able to discriminate and determine them.
Those who are led by reason are the disciples of the Buddha.
Those who are not led by reason are the non-Buddhists.
Those who are not led by either are the other sentient beings.
Its activity is that of eliminating doubt.
Because wisdom is able to discriminate and attain certainty regarding dharmas.
What is faith?
It is the deep and correct conformity to karma, its fruits, the truths, and the Three Jewels, with mental purity as its nature.
Regarding karma, it refers to meritorious, non-meritorious, and immovable karma.
Regarding its fruits, it refers to the fruits of stream-entry, once-returning, non-returning, and arhatship.
Regarding the truths, it refers to the truths of suffering, accumulation, cessation, and the path.
Regarding the Three Jewels, it refers to the Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha.
Deeply and correctly conforming to such karma, its fruits, and so forth, is also called purity and aspiration.
Its activity is that of serving as the basis for desire.
What is conscience?
It has the nature of shame in regard to offenses committed, in relation to oneself and the Dharma.
Offenses are faults, because the wise despise them.
Shame is the avoidance of offenses.
Its activity is that of supporting the cessation of evil conduct.
What is DECENCY?
It has the nature of shame in regard to offenses committed, in relation to others.
In relation to others means that one is afraid of being punished or criticized by others, and one is ashamed of offenses in relation to others.
Its activity is the same as that of conscience.
What is NONGREED?
It is the antidote to greed, has deep disgust for the latter, and has nonattachment as its nature.
Greed is attachment to existence and the implements of existence. Its antidote is called nonattachment.
This means the absence of attachment to existence and the implements of existence. It is called deep disgust because it thoroughly understands the faults of samsara.
Its activity is that of supporting the nonarising of evil conduct.
What is NONHATRED?
That is, it is the opposite of anger and has loving-kindness as its nature.
It means not harming sentient beings.
Its activity is as explained for noncovetousness.
What is nondelusion?
It is the opposite of delusion and has correct knowledge of reality as its nature.
Correct knowledge of reality is, in brief, the four noble truths, and in detail, the twelve members of dependent origination. Correct knowledge of reality is the activity of the path.
Its activity is also as explained for noncovetousness.
What is effort?
It is the opposite of laziness and has as its nature the vigor of manifesting good dharmas.
It means donning armor, practice, not being cowardly, not turning back, and not being satisfied.
Its activity is that of perfecting and accomplishing good dharmas.
What is serenity?
It is the opposite of torpor and has as its nature the fitness and suppleness of body and mind. It means being able to discard the ten kinds of evil behavior.
Its activity is that of eliminating hindrances.
By the power of this, one eliminates all hindrances and discards torpor.
What is non-negligence?
It is the antidote to negligence. It is based on non-greed, up to vigor, and abandoning unwholesome dharmas and cultivating their antidotes, the wholesome dharmas.
Greed, hatred, delusion, and laziness are called negligence. The antidote to them is non-negligence.
It is based on the four dharmas of non-greed, non-hatred, non-delusion, and vigor, the antidote to unwholesome dharmas, and the cultivation of wholesome dharmas.
Its activity is to be the basis for correct practice in the world and beyond.
What is equanimity?
It is the equality of mind, the uprightness of mind, and the effortless state of mind that is attained based on non-greed, non-hatred, up to vigor.
Moreover, by this, one is free from defiled dharmas and abides in pure dharmas.
It is because of the nature of non-greed, non-hatred, non-delusion, and vigor, or sometimes because of being free from the faults of dullness and agitation, that one first attains an equal mind;
Sometimes it is spontaneous and without effort, and therefore next it attains a straight mind.
Sometimes it is far removed from all defilements, and finally it attains a mind without effort.
Its activity is as explained in the case of heedfulness.
What is non-harming?
It is the antidote to harming, and has compassion as its nature.
Because of compassion, one does not harm living beings. It is a part of non-hatred.
Its activity is to prevent harm.
What is craving?
It is defiled attachment and clinging to the five appropriated aggregates as one's own.
It is a fetter that causes one to revolve in the three realms.
Its activity is to give rise to the suffering of birth.
Because of the power of craving, the five appropriated aggregates are born.
What is hatred?
It is the nature of harming living beings.
Its activity is to serve as the basis for abiding in anxiety and evil conduct.
Anxiety means harming others and abiding in suffering oneself.
What is pride?
There are seven kinds of pride, namely, pride, overweening pride, excessive pride, pride of thinking oneself great, pride of thinking one is superior, slight pride, and perverted pride.
What is pride?
It means to think oneself superior to an inferior, or equal to an equal, and to be arrogant in this way.
What is overweening pride?
It means to think oneself superior to an equal, or equal to a superior, and to be arrogant in this way.
What is excessive pride?
It means to think oneself superior to a superior, and to be arrogant in this way.
What is pride of thinking oneself great?
It means to think the five appropriated aggregates are the self or belong to the self, and to be arrogant in this way.
What is pride of thinking one is superior?
It means to think one has attained the Dharma that is to be realized as superior, when one has not yet attained it, and to be arrogant in this way.
The Dharma that is to be realized as superior means the fruits of the holy ones, as well as samÄdhi, samÄpatti, and so forth.
Not having attained it, one claims to have attained it and becomes self-important.
What is low-level pride?
It is the mind's arrogance in thinking oneself slightly inferior to those who are vastly superior. This is its nature.
What is wrong pride?
It is the mind's arrogance in thinking oneself to have virtues when one actually does not. This is its nature.
Its activity is to serve as the basis for not giving rise to respect.
It is arrogance towards the venerable and the virtuous, not giving rise to reverence.
What is ignorance?
It is the nature of not knowing karma, its fruits, the truths, and the jewels.
There are two kinds of this:
one is innate, the other is discrimination-arisen.
Moreover, desire-realm greed, anger, and ignorance are the three unwholesome roots, namely the unwholesome roots of greed, anger, and delusion.
These also arise together, do not arise together, and are produced by discrimination.
The innate ones are found in birds, beasts, etc.
Those that do not arise together are those associated with craving, etc.
Discrimination refers to those associated with views, which are false and definite.
Its activity is to serve as the support of doubt and the passions.
What are the views?
There are five kinds of views, namely, the view of the aggregates as a person, extreme views, false views, holding views as paramount, and holding morality and asceticism as paramount.
What is the view of the aggregates as a person?
It is a defiled discernment that grasps the five aggregates as objects as a self or as belonging to a self.

In this regard, one view is that of permanence, and another view is that of a self that is different from the aggregates, that the aggregates belong to a self, etc.
Why is it also said:

Because impermanence is accumulated, and there is no self or that which belongs to a self in it.
â€œDefiled discernmentâ€ means that which is associated with the passions.
Its activity is to serve as the support of all views.
What are extreme views?
That is, the power of the view of a real self causes one to grasp the self as either eternal or subject to annihilation. Its nature is that of defiled discernment.
The extreme of eternalism is the view that the self is autonomous and eternal.
The extreme of annihilationism is the view that there is a creator, a purusha, etc., and that when the body dies, the spirit is extinguished, like a vase that is broken and can no longer be used.
Its activity is that of obstructing the middle way and the escape from samsara.
What is WRONG VIEWS ?
It is the denial of cause and effect, the denial of function, and the denial of good deeds. Its nature is that of defiled discernment.
The denial of cause means the denial of action and the passions, which together have five parts.
The passions are of three kinds: ignorance, craving, and grasping.
Action is of two kinds: volition and becoming.
Becoming is the seeds of action that are stored in the store consciousness. This is also called action.

This kind of slander is called slandering the cause.
As for slandering the effect, the effect has seven parts, namely consciousness, name-and-form, six sense bases, contact, feeling, birth, and old age and death. This slander is slandering the effect.

Or, slandering the non-existence of good conduct and evil conduct is called slandering the cause, and slandering the non-existence of the retribution of good conduct and evil conduct is called slandering the effect.

Slandering the non-existence of this world and the other world, the non-existence of father, the non-existence of mother, and the non-existence of spontaneously born beings, this slander is slandering function.
That is, the function of going from this world to the other world, the function of seeds sustaining, the function of linking up in rebirth, and so forth.
Slandering the non-existence of arhats and so forth in the world, in order to destroy good deeds.
Its activity is to cut off good roots.
Its activity is to be the basis for the solidification of unwholesome roots.
Moreover, its activity is to give rise to the unwholesome and not give rise to the wholesome.
What is attachment to views?

That is, with regard to the three views and the aggregates that support them, to follow and calculate them as the most, as the highest, as the superior, as the ultimate, with defiled wisdom as the nature.
The three views are the view of the aggregates, extreme views, and wrong views.
The aggregates that support them are the aggregates that support those views.
Karma is explained like wrong views.
What is the grasping of precepts and vows?
That is, with regard to precepts and vows and the aggregates that support them, to follow and calculate them as pure, as liberation, as escape, with defiled wisdom as the nature.
Precepts refer to avoiding the seven evils based on evil views.

Vows refer to the vows of cows, dogs, etc., and to plucking out one's hair, holding a three-pronged staff, the samkhya methods of concentration and wisdom, etc., which are not the causes of liberation.
Moreover, to calculate the great lord or the world ruler, and to enter water, fire, etc., these are not the causes of rebirth in the heavens.
Such things, they calculate as causes.
The aggregates that support them refer to the aggregates that support those precepts and vows.
Purity means that this very uninterrupted skillful means is called purity.
Liberation means that by means of this one is liberated from afflictions.
Emancipation means that by means of this one is emancipated from birth and death.
This is the meaning.
Its activity is that of providing a basis for fruitless toil and suffering.
Fruitless toil means that it cannot attain the meaning of leaving suffering.
What is doubt?
It is doubt about whether the truths, the Three Jewels, and so forth exist or not.
Its nature is that of indecision.
Its activity is that of providing a basis for the non-arising of good dharmas.
Among the afflictions, the last three views and doubt arise only through discrimination, while the others are common to both innate and discriminatively arisen [afflictions].
What is anger?
It is by nature the mind's indignation based on present unfavorable things.
Its activity is that of providing a basis for violence, evil, and holding a whip or stick.
What is resentment?
It is by nature the holding of grudges without letting go, based on previous anger.
Its activity is that of supporting non-forbearance.
What is DECEIT?
Its nature is that of concealing transgressions, that is, concealing oneâ€™s sins.
When one is being properly admonished by others, one does not confess, and this is a part of delusion.
Its activity is that of supporting regret and anxiety.
What is MALICE?
Its nature is that of giving rise to violent and evil speech and of being arrogant and offensive.
It is a mental event that arises from anger and hatred and injures others.
Violent and evil speech is that which is cutting, injurious, and coarse, and it can support anxiety and unhappiness.
Its activity is that of giving rise to demerit and creating a bad reputation.
What is ENVY?
Its nature is that of jealousy of the good fortune of others.
Because of fame and profit, one is unable to endure the good fortune of others, and a jealous mind arises.
Its activity is that of supporting the suffering of anxiety.
What is GREED?
Its nature is that of stinginess that is contrary to giving.
Because of stinginess with regard to wealth, etc., one is unable to give. This is the same as the above-mentioned stinginess.
The mind is attached to all kinds of goods and possessions. It is a part of craving.
Its activity is that of supporting insatiability.
The insatiable person, because of stinginess, still accumulates goods that are not being used.
What is DECEIT ?
It is by nature the deceiving of others by a crooked mind and false words in order to make a false impression.
It is a part of craving.
Its activity is that of supporting wrong livelihood.
What is HYPOCRISY ?
It is by nature a crooked mind that sets up a pretense in order to conceal oneâ€™s faults.
It is a part of craving and ignorance.
Its activity is that of obstructing good advice.
Moreover, because of the existence of hypocrisy, one does not confess oneâ€™s faults as they really are, and one is not fit to be corrected.
What is HAUGHTINESS ?
Its nature is that of a mind that is arrogant and attached to its own prosperity.
Prosperity refers to the prosperity of the impure.
Attachment and arrogance refer to being attached to and delighted by defilements, and being self-important, which are aspects of greed.
Capable of exhausting means that this [mindfulness of breathing] is able to exhaust all wholesome roots.
What is harmfulness?
It means the nature of harming sentient beings, which is an aspect of anger.
Harming means inflicting beatings and other forms of harm.
This [harmfulness] serves as the basis for [anger].
What is lack of conscience?
It means the nature of not being ashamed of oneself for committing offenses.
Its activity is to assist all the fundamental and secondary mental afflictions.
What is lack of sense of shame?
It means the nature of not being ashamed of others for committing offenses.
Its activity is as explained for lack of conscience.
What is torpor?
It means the nature of the mind being disharmonious, incapable, and dull, which is an aspect of delusion.
Its activity is to serve as the basis for all the fundamental and secondary mental afflictions.
What is restlessness?
It means the nature of the mind not being tranquil due to recollecting things such as joy and pleasure.
You should know that it is a part of craving, because it causes the mind not to be tranquil when one recalls the events of former games, laughter, etc.
Its activity is that of obstructing samÄdhi.
What is UNBELIEF?
It is the opposite of belief, i.e., lack of faith in action, results of action, etc., lack of clarity and purity of mind. Its nature is that of opposing belief.
Its activity is that of supporting laziness.
What is LAZINESS?ğŸ”½It is the opposite of vigor, i.e., lack of courage and progress of mind with respect to the good.
Its nature is that of opposing the cultivation of the good. Its activity is that of obstructing the seeking of the good.
What is NEGLIGENCE?
It is the lack of restraint of mind with respect to the passions because of craving, hatred, delusion, and laziness, and the lack of cultivation of the good. Its nature is that of opposing vigilance.
Its activity is that of supporting the increase of evil and the decrease of good.
What is FORGETEULNESS?
It is defiled memory, i.e., the lack of clarity of mind with respect to the good.
Defiled memory is that which accompanies the passions.
As for the indeterminate with regard to the good, it refers to being unable to remember the meaning of correct instruction.
Its activity is to serve as the support for distraction.
What is distraction?
It is a part of craving, hatred, and delusion, and its nature is that of causing mind and mental activities to flow out and scatter.
Its activity is that of obstructing concentration.
What is lack of conscience?
It is discernment associated with the passions, and its nature is that of causing incorrect behavior of body, speech, and mind.
Its activity is that of serving as the support for violating precepts.
Because of incorrect contemplation of going, coming, etc., one does not know what should be done and what should not be done, and thus one violates the precepts.
What is remorse?
Its nature is that of mental agitation.
It is called remorse because of the evil that is done.
The substance of this remorse is not the same as agitation, because it is the subsequent repentance for the evil that was done previously.
This is a case of naming the result with the name of the cause, and therefore it is called remorse.
It is like the case of the six sense bases that are called prior action.
It has two states, namely wholesome and unwholesome.
Within the two states, each has two [types].
If in the wholesome state, one does not do wholesome [deeds] first, and later gives rise to a repentant mind, then the cause is wholesome, and the repentance is also wholesome.
If one does unwholesome [deeds] first, and later gives rise to a repentant mind, then the cause is unwholesome, and the repentance is wholesome.
If in the unwholesome state, one does not do unwholesome [deeds] first, and later gives rise to a repentant mind, then the cause is unwholesome, and the repentance is also unwholesome.
If one does wholesome [deeds] first, and later gives rise to a repentant mind, then the cause is wholesome, and the repentance is unwholesome.
What is drowsiness?
It is characterized by a lack of mastery and a state of obscurity and dullness.
Lack of mastery means that it causes the mind and so forth to operate without mastery, and is a part of delusion.
Moreover, because its own nature lacks mastery, it causes the mind and mental factors to become extremely obscure and dull.
It can be wholesome, unwholesome, or indeterminate in nature.
Its function is to serve as the basis for faults.
What is discursive thought?
It is a kind of volition and wisdom, mental verbalization, investigation, and the nature of gross discrimination of the mind.
Mental verbalization means mental consciousness, which arises either based on volition or based on wisdom.
Gross discrimination means investigating the gross characteristics of vases, clothes, vehicles, etc.
Its activity is to be the support for pleasant and painful contacts, etc.
What is investigation?
It is a kind of volition and wisdom, mental verbalization, and subtle discrimination of the mind.
Subtle discrimination means discriminating the subtle characteristics of vases, clothes, etc., such as whether they are complete or incomplete, etc.
What are the formations not associated with the mind?
They are nominally established based on the states of form, mind, etc., and cannot be said to be either the same as or different from them.
What are they?

They are acquisition, the attainment of non-perception, the attainment of cessation, the heavenly beings of non-perception, the faculty of life, the similarity of species, birth, old age, duration, impermanence, the aggregate of names, the aggregate of phrases, the aggregate of syllables, the nature of being an ordinary person, and so forth.
What is acquisition?
It is obtaining and possessing.
It is of three kinds: acquisition as seeds, acquisition as mastery, and acquisition as actualized activity, as is appropriate.
What is the attainment of non-perception?

It is the cessation of the non-perpetually active mind and mental factors, characterized by the intention to leave behind the defilements of the Pure Abodes but not those of the higher realms, and by the thought of liberation.
What is the attainment of cessation?

It is the cessation of the non-perpetually active and a part of the perpetually active mind and mental factors, characterized by the intention to temporarily stop the thought of the summit of existence and to rise above it.
The non-perpetually active refers to the six evolving consciousnesses.
